title: PM Update: Pleasant into tonight, then hot with some late-day storms Wednesday
text:
Pretty colors at sunset on Labor Day. (Jim Havard/Flickr)

Today was rather summery for what is considered by many the first unofficial day of fall. The astronomical calendar is having a laugh today, given highs approaching 90 in spots. And it’s only a preview of things to come. Nineties seem close to assured Wednesday.

Listen to our daily D.C. forecasts: Apple Podcasts | Amazon Echo | More options

Through tonight: It’s a pleasant evening, if on the warm side. Temperatures are falling into and through the 70s around sunset. Under mostly clear to partly cloudy skies, lows end up ranging from the mid-60s to low 70s. Humidity is moderately high, so you’ll feel it if you’re out there. Winds are light and variable after dark.

View the current weather at The Washington Post.

Tomorrow (Wednesday): Skies are mixed, with periods of clouds and others of sun. It’s probably a bit hazier than today, as well. Highs are mainly near 90 and into the low 90s. Probably one of the last 90-degree days, but will it be the last? While that’s to be determined, there is a lot of certainty that humidity is bordering on high. This should send heat indexes into the mid-90s or even the upper 90s. Winds are out of the south-southwest around 10 mph.



Storm outlook for Wednesday. (Storm Prediction Center)

Scattered storms may develop late in the day. Any that do could be intense. The National Weather Service Storm Prediction Center has this area in the southern part of a “marginal” risk for severe weather, as isolated wind damage is possible from any of the more potent storms. Storms are a risk at any time during the afternoon into evening, but for now it seems that the most widespread threat is focused in the 4-8 p.m. time frame.

See Matt Rogers’s forecast through the weekend. And if you haven’t already, join us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter and Instagram. For related traffic news, check out Gridlock.

Pollen update: Tree pollen is moderate as some late-summer trees flower and counts rise toward the typical September mini-peak. Mold spores are also moderate. Other allergens are low.
